awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant: The University of Texas at Arlington: Center for Concrete Technology: Concrete Advancement Network (CAN)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Concrete Advancement Network (CAN) is a consortium of academic and industrial researchers engaged in bringing cutting-edge technologies to the cement and concrete materials industries, improving the built environment. Cement and concrete represent ubiquitous human-made materials and continue to be widely utilized in construction. Despite a universal utilization, most modern cement and concrete applications are based on relatively dated technology, requiring massive inputs of raw materials. This IUCRC will allow researchers to collaborate on the latest advancements in nanotechnology, bottom-up engineering, recyclability, improved structural design with machine learning, and emergent technologies relating to the improvement of concrete in its use throughout the nation’s buildings and infrastructure. This award supports the planning phase of the CAN IUCRC to enable the team and participating leaders from industry to explore unmet needs, identify promising research trends, and formally establish the 5-year research plan for the proposed Center. The Planning Workshop will allow members and industry partners to establish the research agenda, select the first pool of research projects for the four member sites, and foster collaborative activities. CAN will be led by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, with Arizona State University, Oregon State University, and the University of Texas at Arlington as partners. CAN’s members will facilitate the translation of novel concepts and ideas into scalable and implementable solutions with impact. Industry partners will steer CAN’s research direction and priorities to realization by providing testbeds and promoting CAN’s value proposition and research results to cement and concrete businesses.

CAN’s mission is to enhance the resilience and sustainability of concrete materials and structures through innovations in materials and processing by leveraging use-inspired research and collaborations between academia and related industrial partners. CAN will plan to develop new techniques and methods that will usher the next generation of concrete that is energy-efficient, rapidly deployable, labor efficient, economical, and less dependent on natural resources than existing concrete. The collaborative teams research capabilities will couple scientific advances in concrete materials and design with multi-scale modeling, machine learning, artificial intelligence, and, ultimately digital manufacturing, towards cutting-edge concepts in this critical and massive-scale industrial sector.  At the planning workshop and during the 12-month planning grant period, CAN industry and academic leaders will discuss current limitations, barriers, and obstacles to identify immediate solutions for industry/academic research and dissemination, engineering student education and job-preparedness, and broadening the participation of students underrepresented in STEM. CAN seeks to provide long-term solutions for the nation’s deteriorating infrastructure and meet the demand for future transportation, infrastructure, buildings, and housing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes: NSF’s University-Industry Cooperative Research Centers (I/UCRCs) are designed to help corporate partners and government agencies connect directly and efficiently with university researchers. The proposed Concrete Advancement Network (CAN) I/UCRC is being formed by the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (lead site), Oregon State University, Arizona State University, and The University of Texas-Arlington to:

  • Develop innovative concrete materials and processing technologies;
  • Translate promising research outcomes into tangible impacts for member companies; and
  • Develop a diverse and skilled science and engineering workforce for the concrete industry at large.

On January 31 and February 1, 2022, more than 100 concrete industry professionals attended the planning workshop for the Concrete Advancement Network (CAN), an Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF). Presentations were made by CAN’s university partners and NSF representatives. The workshop was made possible through a planning grant provided by NSF.

During the planning process, CAN leadership reached out to industry partners (150+ interviews) throughout the U.S. and identified 70+ prospective industrial members. The four university teams actively recruited large and small businesses, startups, and nonprofits as potential industry members. To avoid holding in-person meetings due to the COVID-19 pandemic, a customer discovery survey and planning workshop used the AirTable Platform to determine the companies’ unmet and underserved research needs and research interests. During the Planning Workshop (conducted using Zoom and AirTable) and the planning grant period, CAN leadership further identified potential industry members and approved the membership scheme and pricing structure. During the workshop, potential industry partners learned about the NSF I/UCRC program as well as potential research projects for the CAN I/UCRC. Further, NSF and the university partners gathered the necessary information for merit review and final development of the new CAN I/UCRC.

The CAN leadership team aims to solve the challenges inherent in the implementation of new technologies into the construction market. Currently, eight industry partners have committed to support the CAN Center and form the Industrial Advisory Board (IAB). These partners will create the center’s Industrial Advisory Board (CAN IAB), which will further define the scope and focus of each research area. The CAN IAB will ensure that the university partners are conducting research of relevance to the industry members. The IAB also will help refine the mission, vision, and research roadmap for the CAN center. To fulfill these responsibilities, member representatives will attend semi-annual meetings, review research proposals, help select research projects to be funded, and vote on issues as they arise. 

The Phase I proposal was submitted to NSF as the primary outcome of the planning grant and with the required industry support. The proposed CAN will be comprised of two sites, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee and Oregon State University, with external collaborators from Arizona State University and the University of Texas at Arlington.

Intellectual Merit: An important part of CAN’s mission is to enable the resilience and sustainability of concrete materials and structures through innovations in materials and processing by leveraging use-inspired research. The proposed research thrusts address some of the most important challenges related to concrete production and use, including the ecological feasibility of building materials of the future. Enhancing the sustainability and durability of concrete through advances in materials science and processing technologies enables significant societal and economic impacts.

Thus, CAN envisions an interconnected matrix of multidisciplinary experts from industry and academia collaborating to rapidly identify, explore, and solve fundamental and applied problems related to the decarbonization, sustainability, and durability of concrete; a streamlined research and innovation hub that bridges the traditional gap between industry and academia, thereby accelerating research translation into practice; and the translation of research discoveries to meet industrial needs and to nurture the next generation of talent for academia and industry to tackle problems with real-world relevance and significance.

Broader Impacts: The proposed CAN is strategically important to the U.S. economy because it will provide long-term solutions for the nation’s deteriorating state of infrastructure and meet the demand for transportation, housing, and buildings, all of which make extensive use of concrete. The implementation of new materials and processes with enhanced efficiency and demonstrable life-cycle benefits offers a template for methods and practices adaptable across the engineering and building sectors. In addition to the immediate environmental impact of proposed technological advancements, another CAN goal is to raise awareness of sustainability and environmental impact vis-a-vis concrete and building materials in general. The cooperative nature of CAN will lead to streamlining and cooperation between academic and industry leaders, thereby opening new areas of applied research to civil engineers. Housing the Center with top R1 research institutions helps the Center to train and build the next-generation workforce of graduate researchers, scientists, and engineers. The Center will also strive to achieve equitable inclusion of underrepresented groups, including women and nonbinary individuals, as well as racial and ethnic minorities, into STEM fields.
